Award.AwardTitle: VOSS: Virtual Standards Development Organizations: Enhancing Interoperability in Data-Intensive Science

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The success of large-scale data-enabled scientific collaboration depends upon the development of high-quality, useful and usable standards to enable data sharing and reuse. While interdisciplinary collaborations continue to proliferate, the process of community standards development for data and metadata remains a bottleneck in cyberinfrastructure development. Community-based standards development virtual organizations are vitally important for the success of cyberinfrastructure, but little is known about the negotiations and instantiations of data standards within these organizations. This project will undertake a three-year qualitative study of open-participation community standards organizations in the genomic sciences to investigate how they manage diverse stakeholder interests to develop and deploy community standards.

Large-scale scientific collaboration is necessary to answer complex research questions that are crucial for national policy-making and scientific progress. Significant investments are being made in building cyberinfrastructure that uses advanced computational resources to support collaborative science. The success of these cyberinfrastructures depends upon the development of high-quality, useful and usable standards to enable data sharing and reuse. This project will provide guidance in effective standards development processes to the genomics field and others with similar data sharing requirements.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In fields like genomics, the ability to meaningfully share scientific data depends on a variety of standards. These standards range from the methods used to produce the data to the way that the data is formatted and described. Developing these standards is a years-long process that involves defining the standards themselves, building consensus among stakeholders, and supporting implementation efforts. This Virtual Organizations as Socio-Technical Systems (VOSS) project studied standards developing organizations (SDOs) in the genomic sciences in order to understand how scientific data standards are created, maintained, disseminated, and used within a scientific community.

This project focused on (1) how scientific SDOs operate as virtual organizations, bringing together stakeholders from multiple institutions, domains, and locations, (2) how the SDOs negotiate diverse stakeholder interests in the process of developing and implementing the standards, and (3) what factors are related to the successful development and deployment of scientific data standards. To explore these questions, project researchers followed the activities of two standards organizations and one globally distributed project in genomic sciences, including participating in meetings, analyzing the organizations' documents and standards, and conducting qualitative interviews with scientists and other stakeholders. We also participated in biological data collection campaigns and collaborative analysis of genomic data in order to better understand how the standards were being implemented in practice.

The intellectual contributions of this project inform our understanding of scientific virtual SDOs in a number of areas, including the importance of aligning the incentives for standardization with stakeholder values, the necessity for ongoing maintenance and development of scientific standards, and the role of standards in supporting new forms of global scientific collaborations. These results are described in more detail in several presentations, working papers, and publications.

This project also has made a broader impact in better supporting other forms of scientific standardization. The published results discussed above provide guidelines and frameworks for future standards development work. Through the project's collaboration with genomic SDOs and research project, we were able to have direct impact on the development and implementation of specific standards. By participating in SDO activities and presenting our findings at SDO meetings, stakeholders have become more aware of the organizational and social factors involved in scientific standardization. Finally, we worked with a global project in ocean genomics to develop and validate a citizen science approach that both increased the amount of data produced by the project and allowed citizens a greater involvement with environmental research.
